Platform.Title: LT Listeria monocytogenes F2365 4 × 72 k
Platform.Manufacture-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and hybridized by NimbleGen)
Platform.Description: a gene expression microarray was designed to target 2821 protein-coding genes (including putative protein-coding genes). Each of the 2821 genes was targeted by 12 unique 60-mer oligonucleotide probes. Each unique probe was printed in duplicates on the microarray. The microarrays were in a format of 4 × 72 k (4 microarrays per slide, with each microarray containing 72,000 probes) and provided by Roche NimbleGen (Roche NimbleGen, WI).

Sample.Title: F2365_RG_A

Channel.Source: L. monocytogenes RNA after reincubation in TSBYE
Channel.Growth-Protocol: tryptic soy broth with yeast extract
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Bacterial total RNA was isolated using TRIzol method as described by Toledo-Arana et al. (2009). Briefly, 100 ml of the culture at each growth time (13, 17, 24, 168 and 336 h, as well as 8-h regrowth of LTS cells in fresh TSBYE) was centrifuged at 13,000 × g for 3 min and the resulting pellet was resuspended in 400 µl of the solution containing 10% glucose, Tris (pH 7.6) at 12.5mM and EDTA at 10 mM. 60 µl of 500mM EDTA and 500 µl of acid phenol (Applied Biosystems/Ambion, TX) were added into the resuspended cell solution, and then the mixture was transferred to a Lysing Matrix B tube (MP Biomedicals, OH) containing 0.1-mm silica beads. Cells were then lysed using FastPrep-24 cell homogenizer (MP Biomedicals, OH) at speed of 5.0 m/s for 45 s. The tube containing lysate was then cooled in ice for 1 min followed by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm for 10 min. The upper layer (aqueous phase) of the lysate was mixed with 1 ml of TRIzol (Invitrogen, CA) at room temperature with incubation for 5 min, and then mixed with 100 µl of chloroform (Sigma-Aldrich, PA) with incubation at room temperature for 3 min, followed by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 10 min. The colorless upper layer was mixed with 200 µl of chloroform, incubated for 5 min at room temperature, and then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 5 min. The aqueous phase was transferred to a new tube containing 500 µl of 2-propanol (Sigma-Aldrich, PA), incubated at room temperature for 15 min, and centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 15 min to precipitate RNA. Pelleted RNA was washed using 1ml of 75% ethanol (Sigma-Aldrich, PA) and then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 5 min. After decanting ethanol the RNA pellet was vacuum dried at room temperature for 5 min, dissolved in RNase-free water, and stored at -80°C. Two biological replications of RNA extractions from the cultures with different growth times were performed. Integrities of RNA samples were evaluated using an Agilant 2100 bioanalyzer (Agilant Technologies, CA). Absorbance ratios of 260 nm to 280 nm as well as 260 nm to 230 nm were measured using a NanoDrop ND-1000 spectrophotometer (NanoDrop Technologies, DE).
Channel.Label: Cy3
Channel.Label-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and labeled by NimbleGen)

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and hybridized by NimbleGen)
Sample.Scan-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and scanned by NimbleGen)
Sample.Data-Processing: We received the normalized data from NimbleGen (quantile normalization was performed across replicate arrays, and RMA (Robust Multichip Average) analysis was performed to generate gene expression values)). For data analysis, we used Arraystar3 from the DNAstar company by directly inputing the all normalized files. The default parameters may have been used during the procedures. We used student T-test to perform the statistics test.

Channel.Growth-Protocol: tryptic soy broth with yeast extract
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Bacterial total RNA was isolated using TRIzol method as described by Toledo-Arana et al. (2009). Briefly, 100 ml of the culture at each growth time (13, 17, 24, 168 and 336 h, as well as 8-h regrowth of LTS cells in fresh TSBYE) was centrifuged at 13,000 × g for 3 min and the resulting pellet was resuspended in 400 µl of the solution containing 10% glucose, Tris (pH 7.6) at 12.5mM and EDTA at 10 mM. 60 µl of 500mM EDTA and 500 µl of acid phenol (Applied Biosystems/Ambion, TX) were added into the resuspended cell solution, and then the mixture was transferred to a Lysing Matrix B tube (MP Biomedicals, OH) containing 0.1-mm silica beads. Cells were then lysed using FastPrep-24 cell homogenizer (MP Biomedicals, OH) at speed of 5.0 m/s for 45 s. The tube containing lysate was then cooled in ice for 1 min followed by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm for 10 min. The upper layer (aqueous phase) of the lysate was mixed with 1 ml of TRIzol (Invitrogen, CA) at room temperature with incubation for 5 min, and then mixed with 100 µl of chloroform (Sigma-Aldrich, PA) with incubation at room temperature for 3 min, followed by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 10 min. The colorless upper layer was mixed with 200 µl of chloroform, incubated for 5 min at room temperature, and then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 5 min. The aqueous phase was transferred to a new tube containing 500 µl of 2-propanol (Sigma-Aldrich, PA), incubated at room temperature for 15 min, and centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 15 min to precipitate RNA. Pelleted RNA was washed using 1ml of 75% ethanol (Sigma-Aldrich, PA) and then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 5 min. After decanting ethanol the RNA pellet was vacuum dried at room temperature for 5 min, dissolved in RNase-free water, and stored at -80°C. Two biological replications of RNA extractions from the cultures with different growth times were performed. Integrities of RNA samples were evaluated using an Agilant 2100 bioanalyzer (Agilant Technologies, CA). Absorbance ratios of 260 nm to 280 nm as well as 260 nm to 230 nm were measured using a NanoDrop ND-1000 spectrophotometer (NanoDrop Technologies, DE).
Channel.Label: Cy3
Channel.Label-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and labeled by NimbleGen)

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and hybridized by NimbleGen)
Sample.Scan-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and scanned by NimbleGen)
Sample.Data-Processing: We received the normalized data from NimbleGen (quantile normalization was performed across replicate arrays, and RMA (Robust Multichip Average) analysis was performed to generate gene expression values)). For data analysis, we used Arraystar3 from the DNAstar company by directly inputing the all normalized files. The default parameters may have been used during the procedures. We used student T-test to perform the statistics test.

Sample.Title: F2365_336hr_B

Channel.Source: L. monocytogenes RNA after 336hr incubation in TSBYE
Channel.Growth-Protocol: tryptic soy broth with yeast extract
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Bacterial total RNA was isolated using TRIzol method as described by Toledo-Arana et al. (2009). Briefly, 100 ml of the culture at each growth time (13, 17, 24, 168 and 336 h, as well as 8-h regrowth of LTS cells in fresh TSBYE) was centrifuged at 13,000 × g for 3 min and the resulting pellet was resuspended in 400 µl of the solution containing 10% glucose, Tris (pH 7.6) at 12.5mM and EDTA at 10 mM. 60 µl of 500mM EDTA and 500 µl of acid phenol (Applied Biosystems/Ambion, TX) were added into the resuspended cell solution, and then the mixture was transferred to a Lysing Matrix B tube (MP Biomedicals, OH) containing 0.1-mm silica beads. Cells were then lysed using FastPrep-24 cell homogenizer (MP Biomedicals, OH) at speed of 5.0 m/s for 45 s. The tube containing lysate was then cooled in ice for 1 min followed by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm for 10 min. The upper layer (aqueous phase) of the lysate was mixed with 1 ml of TRIzol (Invitrogen, CA) at room temperature with incubation for 5 min, and then mixed with 100 µl of chloroform (Sigma-Aldrich, PA) with incubation at room temperature for 3 min, followed by centrifugation at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 10 min. The colorless upper layer was mixed with 200 µl of chloroform, incubated for 5 min at room temperature, and then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 5 min. The aqueous phase was transferred to a new tube containing 500 µl of 2-propanol (Sigma-Aldrich, PA), incubated at room temperature for 15 min, and centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 15 min to precipitate RNA. Pelleted RNA was washed using 1ml of 75% ethanol (Sigma-Aldrich, PA) and then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm at 4°C for 5 min. After decanting ethanol the RNA pellet was vacuum dried at room temperature for 5 min, dissolved in RNase-free water, and stored at -80°C. Two biological replications of RNA extractions from the cultures with different growth times were performed. Integrities of RNA samples were evaluated using an Agilant 2100 bioanalyzer (Agilant Technologies, CA). Absorbance ratios of 260 nm to 280 nm as well as 260 nm to 230 nm were measured using a NanoDrop ND-1000 spectrophotometer (NanoDrop Technologies, DE).
Channel.Label: Cy3
Channel.Label-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and labeled by NimbleGen)

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and hybridized by NimbleGen)
Sample.Scan-Protocol: NimbleGen standard protocols (prepared and scanned by NimbleGen)
Sample.Data-Processing: We received the normalized data from NimbleGen (quantile normalization was performed across replicate arrays, and RMA (Robust Multichip Average) analysis was performed to generate gene expression values)). For data analysis, we used Arraystar3 from the DNAstar company by directly inputing the all normalized files. The default parameters may have been used during the procedures. We used student T-test to perform the statistics test.

Series.Title: Transcriptomic Response of Listeria monocytogenes throughout the Life Cycle
Series.Summary: A long-term-survival (LTS) phase in Listeria monocytogenes was recently discovered. Cells in this phase are coccoid in shape, survive for at least 30 d without any decrease in viable cell numbers, and are very resistant to heat and high pressure. However, how cells of L. monocytogenes transition to this long-term-survival phase is little understood. Therefore, a whole-genome expression analysis was conducted to study the transcription profile of L. monocytogenes as it enters the LTS phase. Transcription profiles at log, stationary and death phases were analyzed since differential gene expressions at these phases may contribute to the eventual transition to the LTS phase. Specifically, cells of L. monocytogenes F2365 at log, stationary, death and LTS phases were obtained by incubating cultures in TSBYE at 35°C for 13 h, 17 h, 24 h and 168-336 h, respectively. Also, to study cells transitioning from the LTS phase back to the log phase, 1 ml of the LTS-phase culture at 336 h was reinoculated into 100 ml of fresh TSBYE with incubation at 35°C for 8 h. Total RNAs of all samples were extracted, reverse transcribed into cDNAs and then hybridized to the L. monocytogenes expression microarray (Roche NimbleGen). During the transition from log phase to stationary phase, differential changes in gene expression involved genes associated with cell envelope, cell division, stress response, energy metabolism, protein synthesis and material transport. During the transition from stationary to death phase, differential changes were observed in genes related to cell envelope, detoxification, pathogenesis, energy metabolism, protein synthesis and material transport. When cultures transitioned from death phase to 168-h LTS phase, significant downregulation of genes associated with amino acid and protein biosynthesis, as well as stress responses, were observed (P < 0.05), while multiple genes related to cell envelope, energy production and material transportation were significantly upregulated (P < 0.05). High similarity of transcription profiles (r = 0.93) within LTS phase was observed when comparing transcriptomes at 168 h and 336 h. RNA quality measurement revealed a high level of degradation of ribosomal RNA during the LTS phase. The transcription profile at 8-h (log-phase) after re-inoculation of LTS cells also resembled that at 13 h (r = 0.94). We hypothesize that the upregulation of some compatible solute transporters during the LTS phase may result in accumulation of these solutes, which may lower intracellular water activity and thus enhance resistance of L. monocytogenes to heat and high pressure. Dormancy may be induced at the LTS phase which is suggested by the downregulation of genes associated with transcription and translation. Once fresh nutrients are provided, LTS cells may quickly exit dormancy and become metabolically active as they transition to the log phase.
Series.Overall-Design: Based on the annotated genome of L. monocytogenes F2365 (GenBank accession# NC_002973) (Donaldson et al., 2009), a gene expression microarray was designed to target 2821 protein-coding genes (including putative protein-coding genes). Each of the 2821 genes was targeted by 12 unique 60-mer oligonucleotide probes. Each unique probe was printed in duplicates on the microarray. The microarrays were in a format of 4 × 72 k (4 microarrays per slide, with each microarray containing 72,000 probes) and provided by Roche NimbleGen (Roche NimbleGen, WI).
